title: Overall US Job Displacement by 2030
description: Projected net percentage of US jobs displaced by AI and automation by 2030, based on data points where the source directly states a displacement figure.

overlays.label: HBS: 13% decline in postings for highly automatable roles
Stanford/ADP: 6% employment decline for ages 22-25 in AI-exposed jobs
Denmark study: zero effects on earnings and hours from AI (11 occupations)
Frank et al.: unemployment risk rose in AI-exposed occupations from early 2022
Cognizant: $4.5T in US labor value could shift to AI; 93% of jobs have exposed tasks
Goldman (Mei): only 5-10K/mo drag so far; baseline 6-7% displaced; +½pp unemployment

sources.title: The Potentially Large Effects of AI on Economic Growth
sources.excerpt: Roughly two-thirds of current jobs are exposed to some degree of AI automation; generative AI could substitute up to one-fourth of current work.

sources.title: OECD Employment Outlook 2023: AI and the Labour Market
sources.excerpt: 27% of jobs are in occupations at high risk of automation across OECD countries.

sources.title: Gen-AI: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work
sources.excerpt: Almost 40% of global employment is exposed to AI, with advanced economies more affected.

sources.title: The Simple Macroeconomics of AI
sources.excerpt: AI may increase TFP by only 0.53-0.66% over 10 years, with limited job displacement effects.

sources.title: AI Is Starting to Threaten White-Collar Jobs
Forrester: AI And Automation Job Impact Forecast
sources.excerpt: AI and automation could account for 6% of total US job losses by 2030, equating to 10.4 million roles. Widespread AI-driven job replacement remains unlikely. AI will augment 20% of jobs rather than eliminate them.

sources.title: AI exposure predicts unemployment risk
sources.excerpt: Workers in AI-exposed occupations face significantly higher unemployment risk.

sources.title: We're not ready for mass AI unemployment
Bureau of Labor Statistics Employment Projections 2024-2034
IBM 2024 10-K — AI Strategy & Workforce Transformation
sources.excerpt: IBM CEO stated plans to replace ~7,800 back-office roles with AI. Company investing in reskilling remaining workforce for AI-augmented roles.

sources.title: Total US Job Postings Trend Analysis — January 2025
sources.excerpt: Total US job postings are 15% below their February 2022 peak. Categories most exposed to AI (data entry, basic admin, customer service) show steepest declines.

sources.title: Amazon deploys its 1 millionth robot in a sign of more job automation
sources.excerpt: Amazon deployed its 1 millionth robot across over 300 fulfillment centers worldwide. CEO Andy Jassy acknowledged that AI will result in fewer people doing some automated jobs, while new roles in robotics maintenance grew 30% at next-generation sites.

sources.title: AI and the U.S. Labor Market: No Macro Displacement Yet
sources.excerpt: Analysis finds no significant macro-level job displacement from AI as of late 2025, though structural shifts are emerging in specific sectors.

sources.title: Future of Jobs Report 2025
sources.excerpt: 40% of employers globally expect to reduce headcount as AI automates tasks. Net displacement estimates range from 5-14% of current roles by 2030.

sources.title: Sam Altman warns AI could displace significant share of jobs
New data show no AI jobs apocalypse — for now
sources.excerpt: Despite fears of imminent AI jobs apocalypse, the overall labor market shows more continuity than disruption since ChatGPT's launch.

sources.title: The Labor Market Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence
sources.publisher: Stanford / World Bank (Hartley, Jolevski, Melo, Moore)
sources.excerpt: 35.9% of US workers used generative AI by December 2025; small positive wage effects, no significant decline in job openings.

sources.title: Labor Demand in the Age of Generative AI: Early Evidence from the U.S. Job Posting Data
sources.excerpt: Job postings for high-AI-substitution occupations fell 12% relative to low-substitution roles post-ChatGPT; effect grew from 6% in year one to 18% by year three. Based on 285 million Lightcast job postings.

sources.title: Steering Technological Progress
sources.excerpt: Framework for guiding innovation to increase labor demand; steering technology becomes more desirable the less efficient social safety nets are.

sources.title: Displacement or Complementarity? The Labor Market Impact of Generative AI
sources.excerpt: 17% decrease in job postings for highly automatable occupations, but 22% increase for augmentation-prone ones — net effect depends on occupation mix.

sources.title: The Anthropic Economic Index: Economic Primitives
sources.excerpt: 49% of jobs now use AI for at least 25% of their tasks (up from 36% in early 2025); augmentation (52%) has overtaken automation (45%) as primary use pattern.

sources.title: Young workers' employment drops in occupations with high AI exposure
sources.excerpt: If fully translated to unemployment, AI-driven employment declines among young workers would explain only 0.1 percentage point rise in aggregate unemployment.

sources.title: How Will AI Affect the Global Workforce?
sources.excerpt: AI could displace 6-7% of the US workforce if widely adopted (range 3-14%). Currently 2.5% of US employment at risk of displacement from current AI use cases; unemployment projected to increase by 0.5pp during transition.

sources.title: How Will AI Affect the Global Workforce?
sources.excerpt: There is no economically or statistically significant correlation between AI exposure and job growth, unemployment, job finding rates, layoff rates, weekly hours, or average hourly earnings.

sources.title: Yes, AI Is Affecting Employment. Here's the Data
sources.excerpt: In jobs with high AI exposure, employment for 22- to 25-year-olds fell 6% between late 2022 and July 2025. Software developers saw a 20% early-career decline. Employment among workers 30 and older grew 6-13%.

sources.title: AI, Productivity, and Labor Markets: A Review of the Empirical Evidence
sources.excerpt: No measurable change in job openings or aggregate employment in AI-exposed occupations; adjustment happening through task reallocation, not broad displacement.

sources.title: AI and jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
sources.excerpt: Productivity gains 20-60% in controlled RCTs, 15-30% in field experiments; AI exposure measures converge toward high-wage jobs being most exposed.

sources.title: The Adoption of ChatGPT
sources.excerpt: Study of 11 occupations in Denmark: essentially zero effects on earnings and hours worked; confidence intervals rule out effects larger than 2%. AI adoption linked to ~4% occupational switching.

sources.title: AI Exposure and Unemployment Risk
sources.excerpt: Unemployment risk in AI-exposed occupations rose beginning early 2022; graduates with AI-exposed curricula have higher first-job pay and shorter job searches post-ChatGPT.

sources.title: Firm Data on AI
sources.excerpt: Survey of ~6,000 executives across US, UK, Germany, Australia. 90%+ report no employment impact from AI over the past 3 years. Firms expect AI to reduce employment by 0.7% over the next 3 years (US: -1.2%). Employees, by contrast, expect +0.5% job creation.

sources.title: New Work, New World 2026: How AI is Reshaping Work
sources.excerpt: Education task exposure jumped from 11% to 49% — a 4.5x increase driven by multimodal AI, advanced reasoning, and agentic systems. Based on reassessment of 18,000 tasks across 1,000 O*NET occupations.

sources.title: AI and the US Labor Market: Current Impact and Outlook
sources.excerpt: AI's labor market impact still small — only 5-10K/month drag on net job growth. Only 2½% of jobs exposed to automation today. Baseline forecast: 6-7% of workers displaced (range 3-14%), lowering annual hiring by 1M jobs and raising unemployment ~½pp. US creates 30M gross new jobs/year; does not anticipate job apocalypse. Impact so far largely confined to tech sector but expects it to grow materially.
